questions.text: A 24-year-old woman at 8 weeks gestation presents with progressive fatigue since 1 month. She has had a 3.2-kg weight loss after conceiving despite an increase in appetite. She has become increasingly anxious and has trouble falling asleep. The globes of the eyes are prominent. The thyroid gland is firm and diffusely enlarged. Serum TSH concentration is 0.1 μU/mL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
• This patient presents with features suggestive of Graves disease: hyperthyroidism (weight loss, fatigue, anxiety, insomnia, tachycardia, systolic, TSH), Graves ophthalmopathy (exophthalmos), and a diffusely enlargedgoiter.
  • For a pregnant woman with Graves disease, propylthiouracil is the therapy of choice during the first trimester.
    • Propylthiouracil (PTU) crosses the placenta less readily and is associated with a lower risk of birth defects when compared with methimazole. During therapy, T3 and T4 levels should be checked every 3 weeks and the dose of PTU should be decreased once the mother is euthyroid or only mildly hyperthyroid so that fetal hypothyroidism does not occur.
    • During the second and third trimester, methimazole is the preferred antithyroid drug because PTU is associated with a higher risk of hepatocellular damage and agranulocytosis when compared with methimazole.
  • Lugol's iodine can cause a transient reduction in the levels of thyroid hormones (due to the Wolff-Chaikoff effect), but after 5-10 days serum iodine would increase the production of T3 and T4 and thus exacerbate the patient's hyperthyroidism. In patients with Graves disease, the Wolff-Chaikoff effect of iodine can be utilized 5-10 days before thyroidectomy to prevent a thyroid storm. However, thyroidectomy is contraindicated during the first trimester because of teratogenicity associated with anesthetic drugs and the increased risk of fetal loss after major surgery.
  • Beta-blockers such as propranolol and metoprolol are safe during pregnancy and can therefore be used as a part of initial therapy to reduce heart rate and treat symptoms of thyrotoxicosis (e.g., anxiety, palpitations, sweating) until the patient becomes euthyroid. However, atenolol is associated with an increased risk of fetal growth restriction; its use during pregnancy is therefore contraindicated.
  • Methimazole is the antithyroid drug of choice during the second and third trimester. However, it is contraindicated during the first trimester because it is teratogenic and associated with congenital defects such as aplasia cutis, choanal atresia, esophageal atresia, and omphalocele (methimazole embryopathy).

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with male pattern baldness and hypertension is placed on minoxidil. He has had a lack of response to antihypertensive agents with failure to respond to calcium channel blockers and ACE inhibitors. Prolonged use of this agent can be associated with which of the following effects?
questions.solution:
• This drug causes dilation of resistance vessels (arterioles) but not of capacitance vessels (venules). Minoxidil is administered orally for treatment of severe to malignant hypertension that is refractory to other drugs.
    • Reflex tachycardia and fluid retention may be severe and require the concomitant use of a loop diuretic and a beta-blocker.
    • Minoxidil causes serious sodium and water retention, leading to volume overload, edema, and congestive heart failure. Minoxidil treatment also causes hypertrichosis (the growth of body hair). This drug is used topically to treat male pattern baldness.
  • Option(A) This agent is used to treat male pattern baldness.
  • Option(C) This agent is not associated with muscle wasting.
  • Option(D) This agent does not cause uremic pericarditis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is evaluated for Infective endocarditis. He has a history of aortic valve replacement for aortic stenosis. As part of the patient's treatment, 240 mg of intravenous gentamicin is started. The pharmacy calculates that, in this patient, gentamicin has a volume of distribution of 30 L, a half-life of 4 hours, and demonstrates first-order and one-compartment kinetics. Which of the following is the most likely serum drug concentration just before the next dose 8 hours later?
questions.solution:
Optimal antibiotic therapy often requires monitoring of serum drug concentrations to ensure adequate dosing, which is necessary to achieve therapeutic levels while avoiding toxicity (eg, nephrotoxicity due to amino-glycosides). The highest level (peak) of drug concentration is usually ½ hour after intravenous or 1 hour after intramuscular dosing, whereas the lowest drug concentration (trough) occurs during the last ½ hour before the next dose.

The drug concentration (mg/L) can be calculated by dividing the drug dose (mg) by the volume of distribution (V.). V, refers to the theoretically required volume (in liters) if the drug were contained completely in the plasma. It can vary depending on how well the drug distributes into tissues; the higher the V, the greater the drug binds to the tissues. When drug metabolism occurs via first-order kinetics, the half-life (tu) represents the amount of time required to lower the drug concentration by 50%

In this example, the first dose of the drug is 240 mg, V, is 30 L, and tix is 4 hours. The initial drug concentration is the dose (240 mg) divided by the V_ (30 L), which equals 8 mg/L. After the first half-life (4 hours), the drug concentration will decrease by half to 4 mg/L. After the next half-life (4 hours later, or 8 hours after the initial dose), the drug concentration will decrease by half again to 2 mg/L

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with recent onset of weakness of her hands, diplopia, and difficulty swallowing. She has been treated for myasthenia gravis for several years. Which of the following is the best drug for distinguishing between myasthenic crisis and cholinergic crisis ?
questions.solution:
Any of the cholinesterase inhibitors (choices B, C, or D) would effectively correct myasthenic crisis.

However, because cholinergic crisis (if that is what is causing the symptoms) would be worsened by a cholinomimetic, we choose the shortest-acting cholinesterase inhibitor, edrophonium.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man complaints of shortness of breath when going for walk.. An echocardiography shows an ejection fraction of 30% (normal > 55%). Laboratory studies show a fasting blood glucose level of 248 mg/dL and creatinine of 1.6 mg/dL. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of a drug that is contraindicated for use in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Thiazolidinediones, such as pioglitazone and rosiglitazone, are antidiabetic agents that increase insulin sensitivity through by binding to peroxisome proliferator activated receptors (PAR) in target tissues for insulin action such as skeletal muscle, adipose tissue and the liver. The activation of PPAR-gamma receptors regulates the transcription of insulin-responsive genes that are involved in the control of glucose production, transport, and utilization. This results in enhanced tissue sensitivity to insulin.
    • As a drug class, the thiazolidinediones are contraindicated for use in patients with NYHA Class Ill or IV heart failure because of worsening heart failure symptoms, fluid retention leading to peripheral oedema, and the promotion of weight gain. This patient has Class 3 heart failure in which he has fatigue and dyspnea on routine activity and cause marked limitation of physical activity.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents with amenorrhea and galactorrhea. Her prolactin level is grossly elevated (200 ng/mL). Which of the following is most useful in the treatment of hyperprolactinemia?
questions.solution: Bromocriptine is an effective dopamine agonist in the CNS with the advantage of oral activity. The drug inhibits prolactin secretion by activating pituitary dopamine receptors.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is presented with shortness of breath, lower extremity edema, and a 4-kg weight gain. She has ischemic cardiomyopathy and rheumatoid arthritis. Therapy is initiated with intravenous furosemide. After 2 hours, urine output is minimal. questions.solution: • Loop diuretics, such as furosemide, inhibit the Na-K- CI co-transporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle and stimulate prostaglandin E release. Agents that inhibit prostaglandin (Diclofenac) synthesis counteract this effect and decrease the efficacy of loop diuretics. NSAIDs adversely affect renal function by inhibiting renal synthesis of prostaglandins, which help maintain renal perfusion in dehydrated states.

questions.text: By which of the following mechanism cancer cells bypass immunity in immune-competent host?
questions.solution: In immunocompetent patients, tumours may avoid the immune system by several mechanisms, including selective outgrowth of antigen-negative variants, loss or reduced expression of histocompatibility molecules and immunosuppression mediated by expression of certain factors(e.g., TGF-β, PD-1 ligands) by the tumor cells.

A fairly diuresis followed treatment, but the ankle swelling persisted. Fourteen days after admission, he suddenly collapsed and died. On autopsy, the left coronary artery was partly occluded by an atheroma, with infarction of the wall of the left ventricle. Identify the lesion in the image.
questions.solution:
• An infarct is an area of ischemic necrosis caused by occlusion of the vascular supply to the affected tissue.
  • Figure shows sharply demarcated pale infarct of the Morphologically, the typical infarct is a pyramidal wedge shape of the affected splenic tissue with the apex pointing towards the hilum, and the base on the splenic capsule. Splenic infarction occurs when blood flow to the spleen is compromised causing tissue ischemia and eventual necrosis. Splenic infarction may be the result of arterial or venous occlusion.

questions.text:
Which of the followings are not the adverse effects of mefloquine?

1. Nausea and vomiting
2. Constipation
3. Diarrhoea
4. Sleep and behavioural disturbances
5. Headach
6. Abdominal pain
7. Peripheral neuropathy
questions.solution:
• Weekly dosing with mefloquine for chemoprophylaxis may cause nausea, vomiting, dizziness, sleep and behavioural disturbances, epigastric pain, diarrhoea, abdominal pain, headache, rash, and dizziness.
  • Neuropsychiatric toxicities have received a good deal of publicity, but despite frequent anecdotal reports of seizures and psychosis, a number of controlled studies have found the frequency of serious adverse effects from mefloquine to be no higher than that with other common antimalarial chemoprophylactic regimens.
  • Leucocytosis, thrombocytopenia, and aminotransferase elevations have been reported.
  • The latter adverse effects are more common with the higher dosages required for treatment.
  • These effects may be lessened by administering the drug in two doses separated by 6-8 hours.
  • The incidence of neuropsychiatric symptoms appears to be about ten times more common than with chemoprophylactic dosing, with widely varying frequencies of up to about 50% being reported.
  • Serious neuropsychiatric toxicities (depression, confusion, acute psychosis, or seizures) have been reported in less than 1 in 1000 treatments, but some authorities believe that these toxicities are actually, more common.
  • Mefloquine can also alter cardiac conduction, and arrhythmias and bradycardia have been reported.

questions.text: Which of the following general anaesthetic Agent should not be used in patient with Acute intermittent porphyria?
questions.solution:
• Thiopental and methohexital undergo hepatic metabolism, mostly by oxidation but also by N -dealkylation, desulfuration, and destruction of the barbituric acid ring structure.
    • Barbiturates should not be administered to patients with acute intermittent porphyria because they increase the production of porphyrins through stimulation of aminolevulinic acid synthetase.
    • Methohexital has a shorter elimination half-time than thiopental due to its larger plasma clearance, leading to a faster and more complete recovery after bolus injection. Although thiopental is metabolized more slowly and has a long elimination half-time, recovery after a single bolus injection is comparable to that of methohexital and Propofol because it depends on redistribution to inactive tissue sites rather than on metabolism. However, if administered through repeated bolus injections or continuous infusion, recovery will be markedly prolonged because elimination will depend on metabolism under these circumstances

questions.text: A 75 years old male patient is known case of COPD and is on combination therapy of LABA + Corticosteroids. Most important action of corticosteroid is___.
questions.solution:
• Corticosteroids have been used to treat asthma since 1950 and are presumed to act by their broad anti-inflammatory efficacy, mediated in part by inhibition of production of inflammatory cytokines.
  • They do not relax airway smooth muscle directly but reduce bronchial reactivity and reduce the frequency of asthma exacerbations if taken regularly.
  • Their effect on airway obstruction may be due in part to their contraction of engorged vessels in the bronchial mucosa and their potentiation of the effects of β-receptor agonists, but their most important action is inhibition of the infiltration of asthmatic airways by lymphocytes, eosinophils, and mast cells.

questions.text:
A : Fentanyl has high first pass metabolism.

B : CYP3A4 contributes to first pass metabolism when it is taken orally
questions.solution:
• Hepatic oxidative metabolism is the primary route of degradation of the phenylpiperidine opioids (meperidine, fentanyl, alfentanil, sufentanil) and eventually leaves only small quantities of the parent compound unchanged for excretion. However, accumulation of a demethylated metabolite of meperidine, normeperidine, may occur in patients with decreased renal function and in those receiving multiple high doses of the drug.
  • In high concentrations, normeperidine may cause seizures. In contrast, no active metabolites of fentanyl have been reported. The P450 isozyme CYP3A4 metabolizes fentanyl by N -dealkylation in the liver.
  • CYP3A4 is also present in the mucosa of the small intestine and contributes to the first-pass metabolism of fentanyl when it is taken orally.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man who is a chronic smoker with chronic congestive heart failure presents for follow-up. He is currently taking captopril and hydrochlorothiazide. Which of the following changes would be increased as a result of this therapy
questions.solution:
ACE inhibitors and thiazides may improve the clinical signs of heart failure. As such, patients may have some improvement in how they feel and may be able to ambulate without as much exertion.

ACE inhibitors decrease vascular resistance, venous tone, and blood pressure. These drugs reduce preload and afterload, resulting in an increased cardiac output. ACE inhibitors also blunt the usual angiotensin II-mediated increase in epinephrine and aldosterone seen in HF. ACE inhibitors improve clinical signs and symptoms in patients also receiving thiazide or loop diuretics and/or digoxin.

  • Vascular resistance will decrease in patients taking an ACE inhibitor.
  • Venous tone will decrease in patients taking an ACE inhibitor.
  • Jugular venous distension is a clinical sign that may improve with ACE inhibitor.

questions.text: A 54-year-old Mr. Green, had a cardiac transplant 6 months ago. His current blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg and heart rate is 100 bpm. Which of the following drugs would have the least effect on Mr Green's heart rate?
questions.solution:
Given clinical scenario in the patient of recent heart transplantation, involves cutting of the autonomic nerves to the heart. As a result, autonomic nerve endings degenerate, and cardiac transmitter stores are absent for 2 years or longer after surgery. Phenylephrine usually causes reflex bradycardia, which requires intact vagal innervation.

Note that denervation may result in up-regulation of both β1 and β2 receptors so that direct-acting β agonists may have a greater than normal effect like Nor-epinephrine and Isoproterenol (Option B & C)

Indirect-acting sympathomimetics are ineffective in changing heart rate due to degeneration of autonomic nerve ending. (Option A)

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with involuntary movements of the tongue and face that started 4 days ago. She has schizophrenia that has been controlled with haloperidol for the past 3 years. Treatment with benztropine is begun. One week later, her symptoms have worsened. Next step in the treatment?
questions.solution:
• Involuntary movements of the tongue and mouth, as seen in this patient, that manifest within months to years following the administration of dopamine-blocking agents like haloperidol suggest diagnosis of Tardive dyskinesia.
  • Treatment options include benzodiazepines and botulinum toxin injection. VMAT inhibitors for moderate or severe symptoms includes Valbenazine. Anticholinergic drugs (e.g., benztropine) can exacerbate symptoms, as seen in this patient.
  • Other options:
  • Option A: Increasing dose of benzotropine can exacerbate symptom of TD and should be avoided.
  • Option B: Propranolol can be used in akathasia but not for TD. Akathasia is a movement disorder that can manifest following the administration of antipsychotic medications (most often first-generation antipsychotics, such as haloperidol). However, it usually develops within the first 1-8 weeks after initiation of therapy. In addition, this condition is characterized by motor restlessness (i.e., a compelling urge to move), which can manifest with an inability to sit or stand still; it does not cause involuntary movements of the tongue and face. Moreover, this condition typically improves with benztropine therapy.
  • Option D: Diphenhydramine, is 1st generation anti-histamine having anti-muscarinic action can be used in place of benztropine.

questions.text: How does 2,3 BPG decrease the affinity of hemoglobin to oxygen?
questions.solution:
2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate(2,3-BPG) is found in large amounts in red cells. It is formed from 3-phosphoglyceraldehyde, which is a product of glycolysis via the Embden-Meyerhof pathway. It is a highly charged anion that binds to the β chains of deoxyhemoglobin leading to unloading of oxygen to tissues . One mole of deoxyhemoglobin(Taut form or T form of hemoglobin) binds 1 mol of 2,3-BPG.

Other options:

2,3-BPG does not bind to alpha and gamma chains.

questions.text: Which physiological adaptation does not happen at high altitude?
questions.solution:
Respiratory Acidosis does not occur at high altitude. At high altitude there is hyperventilation which leads to decrease in the PaCO2 and increase in pH which results in Respiratory alkalosis which leads to altitude sickness (headache, sleep disturbances, nausea, fatigue, lightheadedness).

Other options:

Option A: Chronic hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction occurs due to lack of smooth muscles in pulmonary arteries leading to increase in pulmonary vascular resistance resulting in hypertension, right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH).

Option B: At high altitude the total barometric pressure decreases so atmospheric oxygen decreases so there is decrease in PaO2 leading to hypoxic hypoxia.

Option C: At high altitude there is increased secretion of erythropoietin resulting in polycythemia (abnormal increase in RBC count).

questions.text: Patient was presented with jaw swelling and weight loss. Suspecting malignancy, submandibular gland was resected. Which of the most likely nerves to be damaged during submandibular gland resection?
questions.solution:
Submandibular duct:

  • It is thin walled, and is about 5 cm long.
  • It emerges at the anterior end of the deep part of the gland and runs upwards and forwards on the hyoglossus, between the lingual and hypoglossal nerves.
  • At the anterior border of the hyoglossus, the duct is crossed by the lingual nerve. This is commonly injured during removal of duct.
  • It opens on the floor of the mouth, on the summit of the sublingual papilla, at the side of the frenulum of the tongue.

questions.text: Discriminative touch sensation is due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Meissner's Corpuscle is a relatively large receptor located in the dermal ridges of the glabrous (hairless) skin. This is an elongated encapsulated nerve ending of a large (type Aβ) myelinated sensory nerve fiber. This is a rapidly adapting receptor that senses vibration sensation, tactile discrimination, precise location, tapping and flutter.

Other options:

Option A: Merkel's Disks are the most superficial mechanoreceptor present in the epidermis of glabrous and hairy skin. They are slowly adapting a mechanoreceptor that senses touch-pressure.

Option C: Ruffini's Endings are smallest mechanoreceptors present in both glabrous and hairy skin. They are slowly adapting receptors that usually receive the sensation of crude touch.

Option D: Pacinian Corpuscles are mechanoreceptors located in the skin and deep tissues. They are rapidly adapting mechanoreceptors capable of receiving high frequency vibration. Therefore, it senses vibration and fine touch and can also sense pressure sensation.

questions.text: Absent graft vs host reaction in patients with bare lymphocyte disease is due to deficiency of
questions.solution:
Bare lymphocyte syndrome, type II (BLS II) is a rare recessive genetic condition in which a group of genes called the major histocompatibility complex class II (MHC class II) are not expressed. It's a type of severe immunodeficiency

Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) spans a constellation of genetically distinct syndromes, all having in common impaired development of mature T lymphocytes and/or B lymphocytes and defects in both humoral and cell-mediated immunity. Affected infants present with thrush (oral candidiasis), severe diaper rash, and failure to thrive. Some infants develop a generalized rash shortly after birth because maternal T cells are transferred across the placenta and attack the fetus, causing GVHD. Children with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including Candida albicans, Pneumocystis jiroveci, Pseudomonas, cytomegalovirus, varicella, and a whole host of bacteria. Without HSC transplantation, death occurs within the first year of life. Often, the defect resides in the T-cell compartment, with a secondary impairment of humoral immunity. Two major forms are described next.

  • X-linked SCID. Approximately half of the cases of SCID are X-linked; these are caused by mutations in the gene encoding the common γ (γc) chain shared by the receptors for the cytokines IL-2, IL-4, IL-7, IL-9, and IL-15. Of these cytokines, defective IL-7 signaling is the most important underlying basis of SCID because this cytokine is responsible for stimulating the survival and expansion of immature B and T cell precursors in the generative lymphoid organs.
  • Autosomal recessive SCID. Another 40% to 50% of SCID cases follow autosomal recessive patterns of inheritance, with approximately half of these caused by mutations in adenosine deaminase (ADA), an enzyme involved in purine metabolism. ADA deficiency results in accumulation of adenosine and deoxyadenosine triphosphate metabolites, which inhibit DNA synthesis and are toxic to lymphocytes. Other autosomal recessive forms of SCID result variously from defects in another purine metabolic pathway, primary failure of class II MHC expression, or mutations in genes encoding the recombinase responsible for the rearrangement of lymphocyte antigen-receptor genes.

questions.text: Which of the following is an NK-cell marker?
questions.solution:
NK cells comprise about 10-15% of circulating lymphocytes. These lymphocytes do not have B or T cell markers, nor are these cells dependent upon thymus for development unlike CD4+ and CD8+ T cells. NK cells carry surface molecules of CD2, CD16 and CD56, but negative for T cell marker CD3. NK cells are morphologically distinct from B and T cells in being large granular lymphocytes. NK cells are part of the natural or innate immunity. These cells recognise antibody-coated target cells and bring about killing of the target directly; this process is termed as antibody dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity (ADCC). This mechanism is particularly operative against viruses and tumour cells.

NK cells (Natural killer cells) are defined as large granular lymphocytes that are essential in the innate immune system. NK cells are derived from the common lymphoid progenitor generating B and T lymphocytes.

In humans, there are several stages of NK development in the bone marrow, which are based on the expression levels of CD34, CD117, CD56 and CD94. These phenotypes are restricted to the bone marrow and are not found in lymph nodes, spleen or peripheral blood. NK maturation begins with the expression of CD56 followed by simultaneous expression of CD94/NKG2A. Also crucial to the development of NK cells from common precursors is the expression of CD122 (IL 2/15 receptor beta).

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy came with bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. What are the probable diagnosis, cells, and viruses associated with the image given below?
questions.solution:
Hodgkin's disease (HD) primarily arises within the lymph nodes and involves the extranodal sites secondarily. This group comprises about 8% of all cases of lymphoid neoplasms. The incidence of the disease has bimodal peaks-one in young adults between the age of 15 and 35 years and the other peak after the 5th decade of life. The HD is more prevalent in young adult males than females. The classical diagnostic feature is the presence of the Reed-Sternberg (RS) cell (or Dorothy-ReedSternberg cell).

The diagnosis of Hodgkin's disease rests on identification of RS cells, though uncommonly similar cells can occur in infectious mononucleosis and other forms of lymphomas.

The figure is of the Classical Reed Sternberg cell. The identification of classical RS cells in the characteristic cytologic environment of normal inflammatory cells is essential for diagnosis of Hodgkin's lymphoma. The classical RS cell is a giant cell (20-30 µ) having two nuclei or two nuclear lobes, which may appear as mirror images. Each nuclear lobe or each nucleus contains a prominent inclusion-like eosinophilic nucleolus surrounded by a clear zone ("owl-eyed" nucleoli). The cytoplasm is usually abundant and faintly eosinophilic or amphophilic. The mononuclear form has the same morphological features as the classical RS cell except a single nucleus and is called Hodgkin's cell.

The difference between Hodgkin lymphoma and non hodgkin's lymphoma is as follow:

The oncogenic role played by EBV is more direct in EBV-positive B-cell lymphomas in immunosuppressed patients. EBV is implicated in the pathogenesis of Burkitt lymphomas, lymphomas in immunosuppressed patients,Hodgkin lymphoma, uncommon T-cell and NK-cell tumors, nasopharyngeal carcinoma, a subset of gastric carcinoma, and rarely sarcomas.

questions.text: Irradiation of red blood cells prior to transfusion prevents which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
Transfusion of gamma-irradiated red cells is indicated for prevention of graft-versus host disease in susceptible individuals like:

  • Immunodeficient individuals, and
  • Patients receiving blood from first-degree relatives. Lymphocytes from donor blood react against the tissues of the recipient. Gamma irradiation (25 Gy) inhibits replication of donor lymphocytes.

questions.text: ESR has increased in pregnancy due to elevation of
questions.solution:
The density of single erythrocytes is the same as that of plasma, and sedimentation does not occur until aggregation or "rouleaux" formation takes place4. Both "acute phase proteins" especially fibrinogen (a β-globulin) and immunoglobulins promote aggregation and result in an increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate. In addition, the concentration of erythrocytes in plasma is important; a decreased concentration increases the erythrocyte sedimentation rate as a result of increased rouleaux formation.

As a result of the marked increase in circulating fibrinogen in pregnancy, the erythrocyte sedimentation rate is known to be elevated. However, the upper limit of normal has never been clearly established. Similarly, as a result of plasma expansion in normal pregnancy, or as a result of a decrease in haemoglobin concentration because of anaemia, rouleaux formation is more likely to occur, further increasing the erythrocyte sedimentation rate.

(https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0306545601002674#:~:text=It%20is%20 noteworthy%20that%20the,only%20 slightly%20 influenced%20by%20 pregnancy.)

questions.text: Poor prognostic marker for multiple myeloma?
questions.solution: Serum β2 microglobulin: Estimation of serum β2 microglobulin, either alone or in combination with other parameters, is useful for predicting duration of survival and prognosis in MM. In southwest Oncology Group study, median survival was found to be 3 years with pretreatment serum β2 microglobulin level ≤6 µg/ml, while median survival was less than 2 years for those with values >6 µg/ml. If combined with serum albumin or age, then patients could be stratified into three distinct groups-low-risk, intermediate risk, and high-risk with increasingly shorter median survival.

questions.text: Wilms tumor is associated with all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Nephroblastoma or Wilms' tumour is an embryonic tumour derived from primitive renal epithelial and mesenchymal components. It is the most common abdominal malignant tumour of young children, seen most commonly between 1 to 6 years of age with equal sex incidence.

ETIOLOGY AND PATHOGENESIS: Wilms' tumour has following etiologic associations:

  1. A higher incidence has been seen in monozygotic twins and cases with family history.
  2. Association of Wilms' tumour with some other congenital anomalies has been observed, especially of the genitourinary tract.
  3. A few other malignancies are known to have higher incidence of Wilms' tumour. These include osteosarcoma, botryoid sarcoma, retinoblastoma, neuroblastoma etc.

Genetic pathogenesis of Wilms' tumour is explained as under:

Wilms' tumour associated gene,WT1gene, is located on chromosome 11p13. Normal function of the WT1 gene is synthesis of protein required for development of kidneys and gonads (ovaries/testes). Mutated form of WT1 gene is often caused by deletion in people with Wilms' tumor, aniridia (i.e. absence of iris), genitourinary anomalies, and mental retardation syndrome, known by the acronym WAGR syndrome. As a result of this deletion, affected individuals are missing one copy of theWT1gene in each cell and such individuals are prone to develop Wilms' tumour and several other forms of cancers.

Another molecular mechanism for development of sporadic cases of Wilms' tumour is synergism due to common mutation between β-catenin pathway and WNT (wingless) signaling pathway.

The most common presenting feature is a palpable abdominal mass in a child. Other common abnormalities are haematuria, pain, fever and hypertension. The tumour rapidly spreads via blood, especially to lungs.

Grossly, the tumour is usually quite large, spheroidal, replacing most of the kidney. It is generally solitary and unilateral but 5-10% cases may have bilateral tumour. On the cut section, the tumour shows characteristic variegated appearance-soft, fish flesh-like grey-white to cream-yellow tumour with foci of necrosis and haemorrhages and grossly identifiable myxomatous or cartilaginous elements.

Microscopically, nephroblastoma shows a mixture of primitive epithelial and mesenchymal elements. Most of the tumour consists of small, round to spindled, anaplastic, sarcomatoid tumour cells. In these areas, abortive tubules and poorly-formed glomerular structures are present.

questions.text: Breast biopsy shows the following histopathological image. The tumor cells show PAS positivity. What is your most likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
• There are clefts in the epidermal layers containing large tumour cells
  • Paget's disease of the nipple is an eczematoid lesion of the nipple, often associated with an invasive or non-invasive ductal carcinoma of the underlying breast. The nipple bears a crusted, scaly and eczematoid lesion with a palpable subareolar mass in about half the cases. Most of the patients with palpable mass are found to have infiltrating duct carcinoma, while those with no palpable breast lump are usually subsequently found to have intraductal carcinoma.
  • The pathogenesis of Paget's disease of the breast is explained by the following 2 hypotheses:
    1. The tumour cells from the underlying ductal carcinoma have migrated up into the lactiferous ducts and invaded the epidermis producing skin lesions.
    2. An alternate theory, though less reliable than the former, is that Paget's disease represents a form of carcinoma in situ of the epidermis itself.
  • MORPHOLOGIC FEATURES Grossly, the skin of the nipple and areola is crusted, fissured and ulcerated with oozing of serosanguineous fluid from the erosions.
  • Histologically, the skin lesion is characterised by the presence of Paget's cells singly or in small clusters in the epidermis. These cells are larger than the epidermal cells, spherical, having hyperchromatic nuclei with cytoplasmic halo that stains positively with mucicarmine. In these respects, Paget's cells are adenocarcinoma-type cells. In addition, the underlying breast contains invasive or non-invasive duct carcinoma which shows no obvious direct invasion of the skin of nipple.

questions.text: Which of the following is autosomal dominant in inheritance?
questions.solution: Autosomal dominant inheritance pattern is characterised by one faulty copy of gene (i.e. mutant allele) in any autosome and one copy of normal allele; disease phenotype is seen in all such individuals. Patients having autosomal dominant inheritance disease have a 50% chance of passing on the disease to the next generation.

questions.text: Identify the correct match regarding the drug and its adverse drug reaction?
questions.solution:
Adverse effects of Verapamil

Constipation is the most common side effect. Bradycardia and nausea are more common than with DHPs, while flushing, headache and ankle edema are less common. Hypotension is occasional. It can accentuate conduction defects (contraindicated in 2nd and 3rd degree A-V block) and precipitate CHF in patients with preexisting disease. Cardiac arrest has occurred on i.v. injection and when it is given to patients with sick sinus.

questions.text: A 57 yr old man was brought to the hospital with complaints of dizziness and breathlessness. He has a history of intake of amiodarone, metoprolol, verapamil, lisinopril and amlodipine. During his physical examination, you notice the following discoloration over his face. Which of the following drugs would be responsible for this?
questions.solution:
Adverse effects of Amiodarone

These are dose-related and increase with duration of therapy. Fall in BP, bradycardia and myocardial depression occurs on i.v. injection and after drug cumulation.

Nausea, gastrointestinal upset may attend oral medication, especially during the loading phase.

Photosensitization and sun burn like skin pigmentation occurs in about 10% patients.

Corneal microdeposits are common with long term use, may cause headlight dazzle, but are reversible on discontinuation.

Pulmonary alveolitis and fibrosis is the most serious toxicity of prolonged use.

questions.text: Patient was on an antiarrhythmic drug and developed hypothyroidism and pulmonary fibrosis. Which antiarrhythmic may cause it
questions.solution: Amiodarone is the longest acting (t1/2 = 3-8 weeks) anti-arrhythmic drug. It possesses action of all classes of antiarrhythmic drugs (Na+ channel blockade non-competitive, β blockade, K+ channel blockade and Ca2+ channel blockade). Due to this property, it has the widest antiarrhythmic spectrum. It carries less chances of causing torsades despite prolongation of QT interval. It contains iodine (approx. 37.5%) and can result in hyperthyroidism (similar drug dronedarone does not contain iodine). It can also cause hypothyroidism by inhibiting peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. Other adverse effects include peripheral neuropathy, myocardial depression, pulmonary fibrosis,hepatotoxicity, corneal microdeposits and photosensitivity.

choices.text: Stop warfarin and start heparin plus aspirin

questions.text: A 36 week pregnant female was taking warfarin for prosthetic heart valves and has an INR value of 3. Next step in the management is
questions.solution:
Warfarin crosses the placenta and can cause fetal warfarin syndrome; also known as Contradi syndrome (growth retardation, stippled epiphyses, hypoplasia of nose and hand bones etc.) if used during pregnancy (therefore contraindicated). However, it is not secreted in the breast milk and can be safely given to nursing mothers.

Unfractionated heparin is metabolized by non-renal routes whereas LMW heparin and fondaparinux are excreted by kidney and are contraindicated in renal failure.

  • It does not cross the placenta and is thus an anticoagulantof choice during pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following inhalational anaesthetic agents is with highest respiratory irritation?
questions.solution:
Desflurane

  • It has minimum blood gas partition coefficient and therefore is the fastest inducing agent.
  • It has very high vapour pressure. Its boiling point is 23°C; therefore it boils at room temperature. It requires special vaporizers due to this property.
  • It produces cardiovascular effects similar to isoflurane except coronary steal phenomenon.
  • Induction with desflurane is unpleasant. It causes maximum irritation to airways. As it can lead to coughing, breath holding and laryngospasm.
  • It can also be used in day care surgery.

Binding to tubulin and inhibition of leukocyte migration

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of colchicine in acute Gout?
questions.solution:
Colchicine is neither analgesic nor antiinflammatory, it specifically suppresses gouty inflammation. It does not inhibit the synthesis or promote the excretion of uric acid.

Colchicine does not affect phagocytosis of urate crystals, but inhibits release of chemotactic factors and of the glycoprotein, thus suppressing the subsequent events. By binding to fibrillar protein tubulin, it inhibits granulocyte migration into the inflamed joint and thus interrupts the vicious cycle. Other actions of colchicine are:

  1. Antimitotic: causes metaphase arrest by binding to microtubules of mitotic spindle.
  2. Increases gut motility through neural mechanisms.

questions.text: Muscle not used in overhead abduction
questions.solution:
• Serratus anterior: It arises from 8 digitations from the upper 8 ribs and inserted into medial border and inferior angle of scapula. It is supplied by long thoracic nerve. It pulls the scapula forwards in protraction and rotate the scapula in overhead abduction.
  • Trapezius: It arise from superior nuchal line, external occipital protuberance, ligamentum nuchae, C7 spine, T1 - T12 spines and inserted over lateral 1/3 of clavicle and crest of spine of scapula. It is supplied by spinal accessory nerve. Its upper and lower fibres rotate scapula forward in overhead abduction.
  • Deltoid: It arise from lateral 1/3 of clavicle and crest of spine of scapula. It inserted on deltoid tuberosity. Its acromial fibres are powerful abductor of arm.
  • Pectoralis major: It arise from clavicle, sternum, 2nd to 6th costal cartilage. It inserted on lateral lip of bicipital groove. It causes adduction and medial rotation of shoulder.

questions.text: NaF is used in which color cap vacutainer?

A 65-year-old man presents with several enlarged lymph nodes in his left supraclavicular region. Physical examination reveals painless lymphadenopathy in this region. No other abnormalities are found. A biopsy from one of these enlarged lymph nodes, which is shown in the associated picture, reveals effacement of the normal lymph-node architecture by numerous nodules of uniform size that are found crowded within the cortex and medulla of the lymph node. Tingible body macrophages are not seen in these nodules. Which one of the listed chromosomal translocations is most closely associated with this type of lymphoma?
questions.solution: In general, the non-Hodgkin lymphomas (NHLs) can be divided histologically into nodular forms and diffuse forms. All nodular NHLs, one of which is seen in the picture associated with this question, are the result of neoplastic proliferations of B lymphocytes. Histologically these nodules somewhat resemble the germinal centers of lymphoid follicles, but instead they are characterized by increased numbers (crowding) of nodules, their location in both the cortex and the medulla, their uniform size, and their composition (a monotonous proliferation of cells). These neoplastic B cells express CD19, CD20, CD10 (CALLA), and surface immunoglobulin. In addition, these cells express BCL6, the gene for which is located on chromosome 18. Indeed, the hallmark of follicular non-Hodgkin lymphoma is a (14;18) translocation, which results in the overproduction of the BCL2 protein, which normally inhibits apoptosis. This product is located on the outer mitochondrial membrane, endoplasmic reticulum, and nuclear envelope. It inhibits apoptosis by blocking Bax channels and by binding to and sequestering apoptosis activating factor 1 (Apaf-1).

questions.text: A 40-year-old person presented with 10 x 8 cm swelling in retroperitoneum. Molecular analysis demonstrated t(12,16). Which of the following is your most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Liposarcoma: Most common sarcomas of adulthood.
  • Seen mainly in 50s to 60s in the deep soft tissues of the proximal extremities and in the retroperitoneum.
  • Amplification of 12q13-ql 5 and t(12;16) are characteristic of well-differentiated and myxoid liposarcomas, respectively.
  • Key genes: Chromosome 12q is MDM2, which is a potent inhibitor of p53
  • Contains adipocytes with scattered atypical spindle cells.
  • Myxoid liposarcoma has abundant basophilic extracellular matrix, arborizing capillaries and primitive cells reminiscent of fetal fat.
  • Pleomorphic liposarcoma consists of sheets of anaplastic cells, bizarre nuclei and variable amounts of lipoblasts.
  • The pleomorphic variant of liposarcoma is usually aggressive and frequently metastasizes.

questions.text: What are the muscles which is involved in pain of the marked area ?
questions.solution:
The pain involved here is due to Temporomandibular disorder.

The muscles involved in temporomandibular disorders are the muscles of the mastication; temporalis, Masseter, medial and lateral pterygoid muscles. Three major ligaments stabilize the TMJ; temporomandibular, stylomandibular and sphenomandibular ligaments.

questions.text: The joint between the attachment of the 8th and 9th rib to the 7th rib is a:
questions.solution: The interchondral joint between the attachment of the 8th and 9th rib with the 7th rib is a synovial joint.

questions.text: The arcus tendineus levator ani is a thickening of fascia of the:
questions.solution: The fascia of obturator internus has two specializations. First, there is a strong band on the medial edge of obturator internus that stretches between the spine of the ischium and the superior pubic ramus. This is the arcus tendineus levator ani, which gives origin to the levator ani muscles. The other specialization is the obturator membrane, which nearly covers the entire obturator foramen, only leaving space for the obturator nerves and vessels to exit. Coccygeus is a muscle that elevates the pelvic diaphragm it is found posterior to levator ani. Obturator externus is not found it the pelvis it takes origin from the external surface of the obturator membrane and inserts on the femur. It is an important muscle for laterally rotating the thigh. The piriformis muscle takes origin from the anterior surfaces of S2 to S4, both between and lateral to the sacral foramina. It exits the pelvis via the greater sciatic foramen, inserting on the greater trochanter of the femur in order to rotate the thigh laterally.

questions.text: During an industrial accident, a sheet metal worker lacerates the anterior surface of his wrist at the junction of his wrist and hand. Examination reveals no loss of hand function, but the skin on the thumb side of his palm is numb. Branches of which nerve must have been severed?
questions.solution:
The median nerve provides sensory innervation to the skin of the radial 3.5 fingers of the palm. So, the patient's loss of cutaneous sensation is suggestive of a median nerve injury. The location of the injury also implies that there has been an injury to the median nerve, this nerve enters the hand by crossing under the flexor retinaculum on the anterior side of the wrist.

The lateral and medial antebrachial cutaneous nerves provide cutaneous innervation to the anterior side of the forearm, the symptoms here are not consistent with an injury to these nerves. The radial nerve innervates the radial side of the dorsum of the hand but does not innervate the palmar side of the hand. The ulnar nerve innervates the medial (ulnar) side of both the dorsum and palm of the hand.

questions.text: A patient complaining of anosmia after COVID. It is caused by the temporary loss of function of the sustentacular cells of the olfactory epithelium. Which of the following accurately describes these cells?
questions.solution: Sustentacular cells provide olfactory sensory neurons with a variety of supportive functions, including structural and metabolic support. Both cell types are continuously regenerated from stem cells within the olfactory epithelium throughout the life of an individual.

questions.text: Which of the following is an arterial branch of the vertebral system supplying the brain?

questions.solution: The auditory ossicles form from the mesenchyme of the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches. Malleus & incus come from the 1st arch, while stapes arises from the 2nd arch.

questions.text: The epithelial tissue seen here is
questions.solution: Stratified squamous epithelium: This type of epithelium usually has protective functions, including protection against microorganisms from invading underlying tissue and/or protection against water loss. The outer layer of your skin (the epidermis) is made of stratified squamous epithelial cells.

questions.text: Occlusion of the inferior mesenteric artery is seldom symptomatic because its territory may be supplied by branches of the:
questions.solution:
The middle colic artery is the branch from the superior mesenteric artery that supplies the transverse colon. This is the most distal part of the colon that receives blood from the SMA. Branches from the middle colic go to the marginal artery, which would be able to supply the descending colon, sigmoid colon, and rectum if the inferior mesenteric artery was occluded. The ileocolic and right colic arteries are also branches of the SMA supplying the colon (and contributing to the marginal artery), but the middle colic, which serves a more distal part of the colon, is a better answer.

The gastroduodenal artery is a branch of the common hepatic artery which supplies parts of the duodenum, pancreas, and stomach. The splenic artery is one of the three branches of the celiac trunk. It supplies the spleen, pancreas, and curvature of the stomach.

questions.text: Clinical diagnosis for the patient shown in the diagram
questions.solution:
Gastroschisis : There is a linear defect in anterior abdominal wall through which abdominal contents herniates out. It occurs lateral to the umbilicus, usually on to the right.

Omphalocele : It presents as rounded mass protruding from the umbilicus. This mass contains coils of small intestine and is covered by a transparent amniotic membrane. This anomaly results from failure of coils of small intestine to return into abdominal cavity from their physiological herniation into extraembryonic coelom during sixth to tenth week of IUL.

Meckel's diverticulum : It is a small diverticulum arising from antimesenteric border of ileum. It is a persistent part of Vitellointestinal duct.

Urachal diverticulum : It is a persistent part of a allontois.

Projection of Adjacent Fibres To Overlap To Left Sensory Cortex

questions.text: After a right limb amputation, the patient is experiencing phantom limb. What is the mechanism behind this?
questions.solution:
Mechanism of Phantom Limb After Right Limb Amputation

After a right limb amputation, the patient experiences phantom limb sensations due to the projection of adjacent fibres to overlap to the left sensory cortex. This is in accordance with the principle of somatotopic representation in the sensory homunculus of the primary somatosensory cortex.

When a limb is amputated, the area of the sensory cortex that previously represented that limb becomes deafferented. However, the adjacent regions of the sensory cortex that represent the remaining parts of the body expand and take over the deafferented area. This leads to the overlapping of adjacent sensory fibres onto the cortical area that previously represented the amputated limb.

As a result, stimulation of the skin or residual limb is perceived as originating from the missing limb, causing the phantom limb sensation. The extent of cortical reorganization is also correlated with the intensity of phantom limb pain experienced by the patient.

Therefore, the correct answer is: b. Projection Of Adjacent Fibres To Overlap To Left Sensory Cortex.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK448188/

questions.text: A child presents with problem in walking, seizures and inappropriate laughter. Her IQ is not appropriate as per her age. Which abnormality can cause her symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Imprinting involves transcriptional silencing of the paternal or maternal copies of certain genes during gametogenesis.
  • For such genes only one functional copy exists in the individual.
  • Loss of the functional allele(not imprinted) by deletions gives rise to diseases.
  • Prader-Willi syndrome results from deletion of paternal chromosomal region 15q12 and is characterized by mental retardation, short stature, hypotonia, obesity, and hypogonadism.
  • Angelman syndrome results from deletion of maternal chromosomal region 15q12 and is characterized by mental retardation, ataxia, seizures and inappropriate laughter.

questions.text: A patient presented to a primary care physician with ptosis, difficulty in speaking, breathlessness. He was diagnosed with myasthenia gravis, a neuromuscular disorder. Identify the type of Na+ channels affected in myasthenia gravis
questions.solution:
• The channels which senses the voltage change and opens up are called voltage gated channels.
  • The channels which open up with mechanical changes are called mechanical gated channels
  • When a ligand (binder) binds to the membrane receptor and channels open are known as ligand gated channels.

Key Takeaway: In myasthenia gravis Ach receptor gated Na+ channels are blocked due to Ach antibodies. Here Ach is a ligand.

choices.text: Pyramidal cells in the motor cortex

questions.text: Neurons can be classified depending on the number of poles. In the following list which neuronal tissues are not of the type matching with image?
questions.solution:
• Depending on number of pole neurons can be classified as follows
  • Unipolar : Having only one pole Present in embryonic stage (all developing neurons) in human being

Eg. Mesencephalic nucleus of 5th cranial nerve

  • Pseudounipolar: From single pole both axon and dendrites arise These type of neurons are first typically bipolar but they converge to meet on one side of cell body and elongates to form T shaped process

Eg. In spinal ganglia and ganglia of all cranial nerves except 8th cranial nerve

  • Bipolar: Having two poles Axon arises one pole and dendrites other pole

Eg. In retina, vestibular ganglion, olfactory epithelium, cochlea

  • Multipolar: Nucleus having multipoles Axon arise one pole & all other pole give rise dendrites

Eg. Motor neurons in spinal cord, Pyramidal cells, Purkinje cells in cerebellum

Key Takeway: Pyramidal cells, Purkinje cells are multipolar neurons. In them Axon arise one pole & all other pole give rise dendrites

questions.text:
Various calcium transport proteins are present in the skeletal muscle for transport of calcium. One of them is useful to move calcium ions in the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
Identify it among the following
questions.solution:
• SERCA (sarcoplasmic reticulum Ca2+-ATPase), can concentrate the calcium ions about 10,000-fold inside the tubules. As it pumps calcium ions away from the myofibrils back into the sarcoplasmic tubules.
  • Dihydropyridine (DHP) receptors trigger the opening of the calcium release channels in the cisternae, as well as in their attached longitudinal tubules.
  • Ryanodine receptor (RYR) proteins are found on terminal cisternae.
  • DHP & RYR helps in moving calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum during muscle contraction.
  • Inside the reticulum is a calcium-binding protein called calsequestrin, which can bind up to 40 calcium ions for each molecule of calsequestrin.

Key Takeaway:

choices.text: Reduction of low threshold T type Ca++ currents

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy has seizures. On investigation it is found that he has absence seizures. There is a list of drugs used in these seizures. Boy was given Ethosuximide. The mechanism of action of this drug is
questions.solution:
• Seizures can be treated with anticonvulsant drugs. These drugs are palliative rather than curative.
    • Following are the drugs and their mechanism of action to prevent the episodes of seizures.
    • Ethosuximide reduces the low threshold T-type Ca2+ currents in thalamic neurons. It is useful in absence seizures.
    • Gabapentin is a GABA analog that acts by decreasing Ca2+ entry into cells and reducing glutamate release. It is useful in generalized seizures.
    • Topiramate blocks voltage-gated Na+ channels associated with glutamate receptors and potentiates the inhibitory effect of GABA. It is useful in generalized seizures.
    • Valproate and phenytoin block high-frequency firing of neurons by acting on voltage-gated Na+ channels to reduce glutamate release.
    • Drugs can be remembered as G-PET
  • Surgical intervention or vagal nerve stimulation is also helpful apart from anticonvulsant drugs.

Key Takeaway: Ethosuximide reduces the low threshold T-type Ca2+ currents in thalamic neurons. It is useful in absence seizures.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient has an injury in the lateral white column of the spinal cord on the right side at C4 segment of spinal cord. Patient lost the sensation of pain and temperature. Which limb is probably affected in this case?
questions.solution:
• Lateral spinothalamic tract fibers carry pain and hot and cold sensation from the body.
  • The spatial orientation of fibers in the spinal cord from medial to lateral is cervical, thoracic, lumbar and then sacral fibers.

  • As shown in the figure the lateral fibers are cut, probably the lumbar and sacral fibers are damaged on the right side of the spinal cord.
  • The right side of the spinal cord carries pain, hot and cold sensation from the left side as the lateral spinothalamic tract crosses in the spinal cord as soon as it enters in the cord.
  • So the right spinal cord lumbar and sacral fibers are damaged that leads to loss of pain and temperature from the left side.

Key Takeaway: Lateral spinothalamic tract fibers carry pain and hot and cold sensation from the body.

questions.text: The phase 1 in cardiac muscle action potential is
questions.solution:
• The transmembrane action potential of single cardiac muscle cells is characterized by rapid depolarization (phase 0) due to Na+ influx due to rapid voltage gated Na+ channel.
  • An initial rapid repolarization (phase 1) is due to inactivation of voltage gated Na+ channels.
  • A plateau (phase 2) is due to Ca2+ influx through more slowly opening voltage-gated Ca2+ channels.
  • A slow repolarization process (phase 3) and return to the resting membrane potential (phase 4) is because of net K+ efflux through multiple types of K+ channels.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was evaluated by a pediatrician for weakness and easy fatigability. On investigation the doctor identified that the patient has a defect in the beta chain. What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The hemoglobinopathies are inherited type of hemoglobin disorders, in which there is abnormality in the globin chain.
  • Thalassemia is a hemoglobinopathy in which abnormal globin polypeptide chains are produced (alpha or beta).
  • Another hemoglobinopathy is sickle cell anemia in which the beta chain is defective because of single substitution of a valine residue for one glutamic acid. Here RBCs become sickle shaped when exposed to hypoxia.
  • In Methemoglobinemia fe++ ion is replaced by Fe+++, that reduces the affinity of oxygen with hemoglobin producing anemia.

KEY TAKE AWAY

questions.text: A 37-year-old patient visited the doctor for some symptoms. Doctor evaluated the patient and found that patient has primary hyperparathyroidism. Which of the following is least likely to be associated symptom in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Primary hyperparathyroidism occurs due to excessive secretion of parathyroid hormone. The cause lies in the parathyroid gland.
  • It causes excessive secretion of parathyroid hormone that produces hypercalcemia and hypophosphatemia.
  • Excessive PTH cause excessive bone resorption causing painin the bones and increased risk of fractures.
  • High level of calcium in the blood causing production of insoluble calcium salts in the form of kidney stones.
  • PTH primarily causes increase in calcium ion and decrease in phosphate ion in the blood. It does not affect the potassium level, so it does not produce hyperkalemia.

KEY TAKE AWAY

questions.text: A 40-year-old male has Purple stria on abdomen, and moon face. He visited the doctor for management. He found that the patient has an ACTH dependent tumor of anterior pituitary gland. Probable diagnosis in this patient is
questions.solution:
• ACTH dependent increase in cortisol produces Cushing's disease.
  • Common causes are anterior pituitary tumor, ACTH secreting lung tumor or any other ACTH secreting tumor.
  • Addison disease is caused by deficiency of cortisol in an individual. This person has reduced resistance to stress.
  • ACTH independent increase secretion of cortisol produces cushing's syndrome. Probable causes include glucocorticoid-secreting adrenal tumors, adrenal hyperplasia, and prolonged administration of exogenous glucocorticoids for diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Hypothalamic disorder causes increase or decrease in level of cortisol releasing hormone.

KEY TAKE AWAY

  • ACTH dependent increase in cortisol produces Cushing's disease.
  • Common causes are anterior pituitary tumor, ACTH secreting lung tumor or any other ACTH secreting tumor.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male visited the doctor for sexual problems. On evaluation the doctor diagnosed him with pseudohermaphroditism. Among the following probable cause is
questions.solution:
• Hermaphroditism means intersex or mixed pattern of female and male reproductive organs.
  • 46, XY intersex (Male type pseudohermaphroditism)
    • when the patient has male chromosomes but the external genitals are not completely formed or are clearly female genitals, or are ambiguous.
    • The testes could be normal, absent, or malformed.

Probable causes are

  • Defective testicular development. Because the testes also secrete MIS, genetic males with defective testes have female internal genitalia.
  • 5α-reductase deficiency, in which the enzyme responsible for the formation of dihydrotestosterone, the active form of testosterone, is decreased. DHT is important for development of male external genitals and secondary sexual characteristics.
  • Mutations in the androgen receptor gene, and the resulting defects in receptor function.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: The cervical mucus changes its consistency in different phases of cycle. In a 24-year-old female on examination of cervical mucus, a fern-like pattern is seen when spread on slide. It occurs due to
questions.solution:
• The mucosa of the cervix does not go under cyclic changes like uterine endometrium but the mucus secreted varies in consistency during the cycle.
  • Estrogen makes the mucus thinner and more alkaline, changes that promote the survival and transport of sperm. When spreaded on the slide it produces a fern like pattern on drying.
  • Thinnest mucus occurs at the time of ovulation shows spinnbarkeit effect (thin thread that may be 8-12 cm or more in length is seen when a drop is stretched.
  • Progesterone makes the mucus thick and cellular. It can not produce a fern pattern.
  • Prostaglandin and FSH does not influence the fern pattern in cervical mucus.

Key Takeaway:

  • Estrogen makes the mucus thinner and more alkaline, changes that promote the survival and transport of sperm. When spreaded on the slide it produces a fern like pattern on drying.
  • Progesterone makes the mucus thick and cellular. It can not produce a fern pattern.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a factor to calculate the clearance of substance?
questions.solution:
• Clearance of a substance refers to the volume of plasma from which a substance is completely removed by the kidneys per unit time.
  • It gives an idea about the efficiency with which the kidneys can excrete a substance from the bloodstream into the urine.
  • Clearance of a substance can be measured by
    • Clearance (C) = U*V/P
    • U= Urine concentration of particular substance
    • V= Rate of urine flow
    • P= Plasma concentration of substance
  • Clearance of PAH (CPAH) is used to measure the effective renal plasma flow.

KEY TAKE AWAY

  • Clearance (C) = U*V/P
  • U= Urine concentration of particular substance
  • V= Rate of urine flow
  • P= Plasma concentration of substance

choices.text: Ascending limb of Loop of Henle

questions.text: The aquaporin I channels for water transport are found in
questions.solution:
• The membrane protein aquaporin (water channels) is involved in rapid diffusion of water.
  • Aquaporins are 1 to 13 in number.
  • Aquaporin-1 is localized to both the basolateral and apical membrane of the proximal tubules also in the descending limb of the loop of Henle.
    • Function: It allows water to move rapidly out of the tubule along the osmotic gradients set up by active transport of solutes, and isotonicity is maintained.
  • Ascending limb of the loop of henle is impermeable to water as there are no water channels on its membrane.
  • Aquaporin II is found on the collecting duct. It is influenced by vasopressin via V2 receptors.
    • Function: Under the influence of vasopressin the principal cells in the collecting duct increase the number of aquaporin II to increase water reabsorption.
  • In the skin there is aquaporin III.

KEY TAKE AWAY

questions.text: The pulse of the radial artery at the wrist is felt immediately lateral to which tendon?
questions.solution: The radial artery runs on the radial side of the wrist, lateral to the tendon of flexor carpi radialis. So, the radial pulse will be felt immediately lateral to this tendon. Remember the radial artery enters the wrist on the anterior side. This means that the extensor tendons, which are on the posterior side of the wrist, will not be involved with the radial artery! The tendons for flexor digitorum profundus and superficialis are found more towards the center of the wrist, not on the wrist's lateral side. These tendons cross under the flexor retinaculum to reach the hand.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient presented with weakness, hematuria and other vague symptoms. Proper clinical examination shows presence of palpable purpura. Laboratory investigations performed show presence of proteinuria (2+) and MPO-ANCA positivity. Histopathological examination of the vessel shows fibrinoid necrosis without granuloma as shown below. Based on the above histopathological findings, what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Microscopic polyangiitis is a necrotizing vasculitis that generally affects capillaries as well as small arterioles and venules. Unlike PAN, all lesions of microscopic polyangiitis tend to be of the same age in any given patient, suggesting a single episode of antibody or immune complex deposition. It is also called hypersensitivity vasculitis or leukocytoclastic vasculitis. The skin, mucous membranes, lungs, brain, heart, gastrointestinal tract, kidneys, and muscle all can be involved. Most cases are associated with MPO-ANCA positivity. Microscopic polyangiitis is characterized by segmental fibrinoid necrosis of the media with focal transmural necrotizing lesions; granulomatous inflammation is absent.

questions.text: Which of the following substance/s is/are involved in peristalsis?
questions.solution:
• Peristalsis is the involuntary muscle contractions in the form of waves that move food, liquid, and other substances through the digestive tract.
  • Its function is to propel the food forward to the caudal region.
  • It is initiated by local stretch releases of serotonin, which activates sensory neurons that activate the myenteric plexus.
  • It occurs with the relaxation wave ahead of the bolus of food and contraction wave behind the bolus progressing towards the caudal region.
  • Cholinergic neurons passing in an anterograde direction activate neurons that secrete nitric oxide (NO) and vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP), producing the relaxation ahead of the stimulus.
  • Cholinergic neurons passing in a retrograde direction in the plexus activate neurons that release substance P and acetylcholine, causing smooth muscle contraction behind the bolus.

Key Takeaway:

choices.text: Both statements are true and causally related
Both statements are true but not causally related
The first statement is true and second is false
The first statement is false and second is true

questions.text:
Assertion: Replicative senescence occurs in aging cells.

Reason: Progressive shortening of telomeres results in cell cycle arrest.
questions.solution: Replicative senescence occurs in aging cells because of progressive shortening of telomeres, which ultimately results in cell cycle arrest.

questions.text: What kind of activity at receptor level is depicted in below figure as C?
questions.solution:
The following terms are used in describing drug-receptor interaction:

Agonist

An agent which activates a receptor to produce an effect similar to that of the physiological signal molecule.

Inverse agonist

An agent which activates a receptor to produce an effect in the opposite direction to that of the agonist.

Antagonist

An agent which prevents the action of an agonist on a receptor or the subsequent response, but does not have any effect of its own.

Partial agonist

An agent which activates a receptor to produce submaximal effect but antagonizes the action of a full agonist.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy has a history of progressive developmental delay, ataxia, seizures, and inappropriate laughter since infancy. The child has a normal karyotype of 46,XY, but DNA analysis shows that he has inherited both of his number 15 chromosomes from his father. These findings are most likely to be indicative of which of the following genetic mechanisms?
questions.solution: This child has features of Angelman syndrome, and the DNA analysis shows uniparental disomy. The Angelman gene encoded on chromosome 15 is subject to genomic imprinting. It is silenced on the paternal chromosome 15, but is active on the maternal chromosome 15. If the child lacks maternal chromosome 15, there is no active Angelman gene in the somatic cells. This gives rise to the abnormalities typical of this disorder. The same effect occurs when there is a deletion of the Angelman gene from the maternal chromosome 15. The other listed options do not occur in uniparental disomy.

choices.text: The foramen ovale, rotundum and spinosum
The foramen ovale, rotundum and spinosum and foramen lacerum

questions.text: Which of the following foramina pierce the sphenoid bone?
questions.solution:
The greater wing of sphenoid extends from the sphenoid body in a lateral, superior and posterior

direction. It contributes to three parts of the facial skeleton:

  • Floor of the middle cranial fossa
  • Lateral wall of the skull
  • Posterolateral wall of the orbit

And There are three foramina present in the greater wing of sphenoid - the foramen rotundum,

foramen ovale and foramen spinosum. They conduct the maxillary nerve, mandibular nerve and

middle meningeal vessels respectively.
